data.text: Do You Pack Less or More on Your Cycle Touring Trips Based on Your Previous Experience?

I‚Äôm interested to know, from Bicycle Travellers who have taken two or more long trips, do you pack lighter on subsequent trips based on previous experience or pack more? It would be good to do this as a poll but I can‚Äôt seem to set it up that way.

I walked long distance before I cycled. Walking I chucked about 1/3 away. Cycling I carried nothing that wasn‚Äôt necessary. I cut my toothbrush short but then got nerve damage in my hands and couldn‚Äôt hold it. So I traded back up to a full size toothbrush. üôÑüòÇ
data.author: Ffinlo Kilner

data.text: reminds me of the 'Mr. Been' suitcase sketch.
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text:
I had to look it up https://youtu.be/lusRxdOO8Wk üòÇ
SUITCASE Bean | Funny Clips | Mr Bean Official
youtube.com
data.author: Ffinlo Kilner

data.text: Every trip is an experiment. Always tweaking what kit i carry but, what i take depends on what i want to do along the way. Currently packing about 15kg for a months cycle camping and ham radio trip. The radio kit adds around 1.5kg to the packweight.
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: I pack less and less over time.
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: You'll trim out and remove what's not important to you, and that will be different for everyone. I like a decent toolkit so I can be independent of help in all but severe mechanical failure, a decent tent so I can have space in 6 days of bad weather, and a set of dry clothes should I spend a day cycling in rain... So, my junk carried = my personal preferences. Personally, what are you prepared to leave behind?
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: my partner.
data.author: Nigel Blandford

data.text: there you have it
data.author: Rob Rushworth

data.text: what size litre bag do you normally carry them in?
data.author: Paul Edgerton

data.text: Ortlieb front rollers on the back and front and a small frame on the road touring up and 2x 5 litre, full frame bag, 1 x 13 litre and a single front roller on mountain bike set up.
data.author: Nigel Blandford

data.text: Road set up
data.author: Nigel Blandford

data.text: Off-road set up
data.author: Nigel Blandford

data.text: Bro, I barely pack more than a toothbrush these days. Some change of clothes. Some mini tools to fix simple issues. And off I go.
data.author: Hayder Al-Mohammad

data.text: I may be unusual but I have a fixed list I take and it hasn't really changed. I wild camp pretty much 100%, and like to carry a few luxuries, like a helinox ground chair, a kindle, etc. Clothes vary depending on what I've bought recently and occasionally I buy a new stove or better sleeping mat but basically I'm sorted.
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: did you go straight to the zero or migrate from the chair one? If coming from the chair one I‚Äôd love to hear your comparison between the two
data.author: Derrick Scott

data.text: straight to the ground chair, I haven't tried the one or zero.
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: The more I travel, the less I pack stuff. Camping gear, clothes, some tools, soap, toothpaste, toothbrush are the essentials. What else would you add guys ? A camera probably, one or two extra batteries and a smartphone also
data.author: Tinovera Ao

data.text: I think most will pack less each time. With odd occasional small addition if realized you needed something on previous trip.
data.author: Duane Taylor

data.text: The more I hillwalk, the less I pack. Emergency basics only, preferably multifunctional. I find I get more comfortable with being uncomfortable over time - I don't always need to be at an ideal temperature or feel full of food etc, I just need to be at an okay temperature and have enough to eat/drink and still enjoy the experience overall.
data.author: Oh Susannah Penco

data.text: I can relate to what you say. Modern life makes us expect a certain level of comfort, it's actually absolutely fine to be outside these parameters
data.author: John Axson

data.text: Love your expression and resonate with ''I get more comfortable with being uncomfortable over time''‚ù£Ô∏è
data.author: Jewella C Miranda

data.text: The trick is to pack light then go to charity shops and get your stuff there, along the way...
data.author: David Eldred

data.text: Same. Even more.
data.author: Ewa ≈öwiderska

data.text: There one area that Ffinlo touched on that's really worth a separate comment. Don't overlook the padding underneath your bar tape that sits on the handlebar. That's one area where it pays off to be generously cautious. All those miles of vibration to the cubital and carpel tunnels in your wrists and hands once damaged can really force you off the bike for a long healing time. Extra padding offsets the cumulative neurological damage that left untreated can become permanent.
data.author: Richard Cheatham

data.text: Yeah mine were fine once I stopped riding. But I couldn‚Äôt hold coins for a month üò¨. Shopkeepers had to take my money. Like being 4 again üòÇ
data.author: Ffinlo Kilner

data.text: We've tweaked over the years. Pillows and a Helinox chair are considered luxuries by some but I think are essentials as I get older. Other musts are sarong(s) as they have so many uses, warm layer, scarf, towel as well as cover up. Neck thingy for cooler temps. Arm warmers for cycling in a t shirt and waterproof, I hate the feeling of my coat on my arms. Two changes of cycling gear and clothes, a Rab puffer for warmth. We've invested in a Hilleberg tent, the husb is an engineer so he can fix anything should it go wrong üòâ
data.author: Lynne Sixtyodd Roberts

data.text: Rab puffer?
data.author: Richard Roussy

data.text: hooded alpine down jacket, very light, packs down tiny, less bulk than a fleece and warmer
data.author: Lynne Sixtyodd Roberts

data.text: Thank you for explaining.
data.author: Richard Roussy

data.text: Of course it is lighter and compact
data.author: –í–ª–∞–¥–∏–º–∏—Ä –ü–∞–Ω–æ–≤

data.text: My goal is to enjoy the trip. So i do not care to much about speed or distance. But if i have a nice extra thing in the evening while camping i can enjoy the day even more. But weight might be limited when you use a plane.
data.author: Uwe Storm

data.text: Less is more
data.author: Dave Prestidge

data.text: I've now done three extended tours & found I packed similar amounts, being away for so long it is comfortable to have a few extras, although on my 3rd tour I used a kindle, instead of books, but much the same with other gear. I discovered what I needed from my first couple of tours across France.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: I've never found time to read as a recreation while touring. There are always so many other imperatives. I wonder how to do it?!
data.author: Richard Roussy

data.text: Hi Richard. Sometimes when free-camping I may read a few pages here & there, I don't travel with a phone so the Kindle is great for some 'alternative' entertainment, sometimes in the day also if i'm on a long, not too-exciting road I may take 1/2 hour out to read. Some evenings after cooking dinner & clearing up I may read, but usually [as most do] fall asleep. Also useful when applying for visas it gives a welcomed break from waiting.
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: I went from books to kindle to using kindle app on my phone, pairing weight as I went. But I‚Äôve read books on touring were people tear out the already read pages out the book as they go‚Ä¶. üòÇ
data.author: Nigel Clark

data.text: Yer, I love having he kindle now, but have never used a phone on any of my three tours.. On the tour to Cape Town, in Gabon, I met a Cape Town'ian motorcyclist (riding to German), whom had the Lonely Planet guide book covering all south African countries, I had the book for West African countries, so we swapped, and as you mention, in turn I tore out country chapters as & when I'd done with them as it was a hefy ol' book! üòâ
data.author: Mark Wallis

data.text: Less is more
data.author: Nicolas Ossysek

data.text: I travel by bicycle partially as a means of transportation, so I bring my life with me. Musical instrument, backpack, heaps of food... So I'm really loaded, but have no time constraints.
data.author: Benjamin Moravec

data.text: I don't have a home base, so I need to carry clothes for all season and two sleeping bags. I'm lowering whatever weight I can, but then, I adopted a 2 kilo puppy...
data.author: Patrice Audet

data.text: Ask a back packer, they travel light and buy what they need along their trails.
data.author: Clyde Slade

data.text: Less is more for me. The less I carry, the more happy I am on my bike.
data.author: Michael Coles

data.text: Try both on short trips before you go.
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: Slightly more.
data.author: Scott Diamond

data.text: I've done six trips longer than 1 month and two year long trips. I travel pretty much with the same gear (replacing whatever wears out) but have added one thing. A simple 16 ounce foldable chair. I wouldn't travel without it. I mainly camp out. Also, I tried some Big Agnes ultra light gear and some Sea to Summit foldable cookware. The ultra light gear isn't durable so i am back to more durable but heavier tents and cookware.
data.author: Steve Hiniker

data.text: lighter.
data.author: Susan Kopczynski Jostrom

data.text: I would say slightly lighter, you refine as you go. Things that you assume are essential you find are not. We've ditched more stuff after a 6 week break in our round the world trip. Improved on a few items..
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: In domestic camping tours with food and kitchen we use front and rear panniers. On international tours we only use rear panniers and carry the S&S coupler travel bags on the front rack (as pictured).
data.author: Rod Wanker

data.text: Did you tape your frame for wear protection or for theft deterrence?
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: both. The bike just turned 30, has over 45,000 miles of touring and dozens of air travel baggage abuses.
data.author: Rod Wanker

data.text: this one looks like my old 1993 Nishiki üòéüëåüèª
data.author: Omare War

data.text: After a closer look I think is not
data.author: Omare War

data.text: No
data.author: Datt Bharti Horst

data.text: My first trip - 10 days - I packed less. I had enough room in my pannier for a loaf of bread! These days I have more panniers but weight is more equally distributed and the panniers are not overstuffed. Now, if I could just remember which pannier I put my extra pair of socks in ...
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Yes and no. No, because: 1. Sometimes you travel without cooking stuff 2. Sometimes you travel with hammock and sometimes with a tent 3. On short trips sometimes you travel even without tent or hammock 4. It depends on where you are whether you need to carry (a lot of) extra food and/or water Yes because: 1. You learn what you don't need 2. Through time in general you end up having better and lighter equipement
data.author: Martin Koole

data.text: After touring and before returning to touring I ultadistance ran and trust me I took nothing I didn't absolutely need and still don't, apart from my Italian coffee maker which I'm taking this year. We all take weight as we get older. Keep it at the absolute you can always buy something en route
data.author: John Axson

data.text: After several tours, I go light, but tweak a bit depending on the terrain.
data.author: Todd Burgman

data.text: Definitely lighter.
data.author: Mary Ervin Pinizzotto

data.text: I found after many trips weight didn't matter at all. I did a big trip which included siberia and mountainous parts of China with a 22kg bike ktm hybrid, wide tyres, all up weight was 64kg and my body weight was 62kg after seven months on the road. I had over 10kg of camera gear and other junk that would now weigh hardly anything. I was only 40 too. 2007. Sonya and Nigel big bicycle bonanza blog.
data.author: Nigel Bates

data.text: You always start with poor choices, since you don't know how to make better choices until you make some trips. So start small with short trips, overnight to local parks, to gain that insight.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: Me and a friend did 2 week trip in Eueope and between us we had one saddlebag, one pair of small panniers and one Barbara. Small tent fitted on rack behind saddlebag. If it didn't fit in any of that space, then it didn't go with us.Simple. novice mistake is taking way too much!
data.author: Keith Harrison

data.text: No stress as long as I can get to a post office to send a parcel of any ‚Äòexcess/not needed‚Äô home to family along the away. I have packed less for warmer weather trips, but hate being cold so take lots for cooler weather, and that‚Äôs when some things become favs and others get the flick home.
data.author: Diane Ridgway

data.text: I am risking a little extra.
data.author: Jaspal Kahlon

data.text: yes
data.author: David Frederick

data.text: After my first trip I made a list of the things I really used and I use that list ever since.
data.author: Christiaan Minderhoud

data.text: Less. Always. Less is more. Unless I am starting somewhere where for the next half a continent there are no spares. Then I take with extra bike equipment, but not 'extra stuff'. Altho in Europe one can be lazy and shop along the way...
data.author: Birgit Le Blond

data.text: Always lighter. It‚Äôs so tough to do it though, but it‚Äôs rare to miss things that you were undecided about. The fact that you were undecided meant it was a luxury.
data.author: Nigel Clark

data.text: I took fold up leather pumps 2 dresses and 2 sets cycling stuff and costume. 2 tiny towels and tooth brush hair conditioner and a comb. Kagool, 1fleece, tiny sleeping bag and blow up cushion to support back ,small tent and don't forget suncream,glasses and first aid kit. 200 miles 5 days.
data.author: Dawn McCluskey

data.text: "Fold up leather pumps" I saw this and I thought "Folding pumps? Of leather? That's different. Why two, and why are you so worried about flats?" Then I realized that that 'pumps' doesn't mean what I'd thought.
data.author: Curtis Corlew

data.text: it‚Äôs a regional British word for at least two different types of footwear one of which is also called a plimsoll but that in itself requires a whole level of explanation.
data.author: Nigel Blandford

data.text: yes shoes that don't take up space I ment
data.author: Dawn McCluskey

data.text: you pack according to the place you are going to tour.. when I toured silkroad I packed a stove - I didnt need it at all. there are food stall everywhere you go within 50km of each other. but not the case for Patagonia where establishments/township could be 300km apart. if similar trip/season/climate, I tend to pack less and less.
data.author: Albert Lee

data.text: I started touring 40 years ago with the usual pannier set up and even had a daypack the very first time and stupid gearing like 52-42 and 12-25 I think(only 5 at the back then). Now, I go as light as possible with nice compact gearing on a titanium frame designed for gravel. Basically 2 kits, I wash one at night and wear the other one, my luxury item is a tablet loaded with books and movies. Cycling shoes with recessed clips so only one pair needed. Now it's an extended saddle bag, a frame bag and a handlebar bag. Love the relatively new bikepacking gear set up. No wide panniers that get in the way in tight spots, a lot less weight on the back wheel and more aerodynamic. I was zipping at 30km/hr+ on nice flat roads in Turkey(Black Sea Coast) and Vietnam's Highway 1.
data.author: Gilles Bonnier

data.text: Everything got lighter but then as gadgets became more of a thing, it got heavier. Sure, I got rid of the photocopied paper maps, but now I had a tablet, phone, wall chargers and cables, portable chargers, and eventually my MacBook air made its way into the backpack along with its cable and charger. I started with no GPS device, now I have one and the charger. I did cut back drastically on tent and camping stuff - I never use one anymore, just sleeping bag (if even that) and a light shelter or find an awning to sleep under. I don't carry food anymore because - at least where I tour - there is never anywhere that I can not stop to buy something to eat, and eating local specialties is part of the fun, so I don't want to carry a jar of peanut butter, instant noodles, a stove, etc. I don't make coffee in the morning. If I can not find a vending machine with coffee, I just go without, so no need for the stove and extra water. Clothing I take less than when I first did it, simply because I know more now that I only need one clean set for after bath, and my stinky riding clothes for when I am riding. Spare tires and repair kit and mini air pump are always with me.
data.author: Kevin Cameron
